questions.text: In a patient with a known bleeding disorder, dysfunction of which cellular organelle responsible for intracellular packaging could potentially result in impaired secretion of clotting factors and other crucial proteins?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Golgi Apparatus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The Golgi Apparatus is responsible for the intracellular packaging and secretion of proteins, including clotting factors. Dysfunction of this organelle can lead to impaired secretion, potentially contributing to bleeding disorders.
  • ➤ Golgi Apparatus

questions.text: Which one of the following membranes has the highest content of protein per gram of tissue?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Inner mitochondrial membrane

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The inner mitochondrial membrane has the highest protein content among the listed membranes, reflecting its crucial role in energy production and cellular respiration.
  • ➤ inner mitochondrial membrane

questions.text: Transport of neutral substances across the cell membrane occurs via
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Diffusion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Diffusion is the primary mechanism for transporting neutral, non-polar substances across the cell membrane, without the need for specialized transport proteins like porins, ionophores, or channels.
  • ➤ Diffusion

questions.text: A child with loose stools for one day presented to your OPD. On examination, signs of dehydration were present and the child was given ORS. It facilitates glucose absorption through which of the following receptors?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) SGLT1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ SGLT1 is the primary transporter responsible for the absorption of glucose along with sodium in the intestines, which is a key mechanism behind the effectiveness of Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS).
  • ➤ SGLT1

questions.text: In a patient with a rare genetic disorder affecting cellular transport, dysfunction of a specific protein clathrinis suspected. What cellular process, crucial for nutrient uptake and receptor-mediated signaling, is primarily associated with this protein?
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Endocytosis

questions.text: Identify the type of transport across the cell membrane represented below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Facilitated diffusion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Facilitated diffusion is a passive transport mechanism where molecules move down their concentration gradient with the help of carrier proteins, without the use of ATP.
  • ➤ Facilitated diffusion

questions.text: Which of the following represents the basis for transduction of a sensory stimulus into nerve impulses?

options.label: A
options.text: Change in the ion permeability of the receptor membrane

questions.correct_answer: A. Change in the ion permeability of the receptor membrane
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Change in the ion permeability of the receptor membrane

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The change in ion permeability of the receptor membrane is the key event that begins the transduction of a sensory stimulus into a nerve impulse, allowing the brain to perceive various forms of stimuli like touch, light, and sound.
  • ➤ change in ion permeability

questions.text: In a volunteer, 10 grams of mannitol was injected into the venous blood. At equilibrium, the urinary excretion of mannitol was found to be 10% and the plasma concentration of mannitol was measured at 60 mg/dl. Calculate the extracellular fluid (ECF) volume based on this information.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 15L

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The formula for calculating the extracellular fluid (ECF) volume is based on the amount of substance injected, excreted, and the concentration remaining in the plasma. Here, the ECF volume is 15 liters .
  • ➤ 15 liters

questions.text: Fick's law of diffusion is dependent on all except:

options.label: C
options.text: The molecular weight of the gas

questions.correct_answer: D. The posture of the subject
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) The posture of the subject

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Fick's law depends on the physical and chemical properties of the membrane and gas, such as thickness, solubility, and molecular weight, but not on external factors like posture.
  • ➤ not on external factors

questions.text: Which structures, equivalent to Z-lines in skeletal muscle, are found in smooth muscle cells?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Dense bodies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ In smooth muscle, dense bodies serve a function equivalent to Z-lines in skeletal muscle by anchoring actin filaments and facilitating contraction.
  • ➤ dense bodies

questions.text: Which one of the following is the best example of the regulated pathway?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Non-constitutive exocytosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Non-constitutive exocytosis involves storage and regulated release of substances in response to a stimulus, making it the best example of a regulated pathway.
  • ➤ Non-constitutive exocytosis

questions.text: Which one of the following is not used for measurement of body fluid volume?

options.label: C
options.text: Evan’s Blue dye for plasma volume

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 125I-Albumin for blood volume

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ 125I-Albumin is used to measure plasma volume , not blood volume. To measure blood volume, both the plasma and the cellular component (RBCs) need to be assessed, usually through radiolabeled RBC methods.
  • ➤ 125I-Albumin
  • ➤ plasma volume

questions.text: In a patient with chronic gastritis and peptic ulcer disease, it is important to understand the role of specific stomach cells. Which factor is primarily associated with enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells of the stomach, and how does it contribute to the patient's condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Histamine, which stimulates gastric acid production, potentially exacerbating ulcer symptoms.

options.label: B
options.text: Gastrin, which promotes mucus production and provides protection against ulcers.

options.label: C
options.text: Pepsinogen, an enzyme involved in protein digestion within the stomach.

options.label: D
options.text: Secretin, a hormone that regulates pancreatic enzyme secretion, influencing digestion.

questions.correct_answer: A. Histamine, which stimulates gastric acid production, potentially exacerbating ulcer symptoms.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Histamine, which stimulates gastric acid production, potentially exacerbating ulcer symptoms.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Histamine released by enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells in the stomach stimulates gastric acid secretion, and excessive histamine activity can worsen conditions like peptic ulcers by increasing acid production.
  • ➤ Histamine
  • ➤ peptic ulcers

questions.text: Which one of the following are used in calculating the serum osmolarity? 1. Serum sodium 2. Glucose 3. Calcium 4. Blood urea nitrogen
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The calculation of serum osmolarity uses serum sodium , glucose , and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) , while calcium is not involved in this calculation.
  • ➤ serum sodium
  • ➤ glucose
  • ➤ blood urea nitrogen (BUN)
  • ➤ calcium

questions.text: Consider the following pancreatic hormones: Insulin Islet amyloid polypeptide or amylin Glucagon Somatostatin Which of the above is/are secreted by beta cells of the pancreatic islets?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1 and 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The beta cells of the pancreas secrete both insulin and amylin (Islet amyloid polypeptide) , while other hormones like glucagon and somatostatin are secreted by different cell types (alpha and delta cells, respectively).
  • ➤ beta cells
  • ➤ insulin
  • ➤ amylin (Islet amyloid polypeptide)

questions.text: Assertion : In the absolute refractory period, the nerve cannot be stimulated even with a strong stimulus. Reason : Majority of the sodium channels are in an inactivated state during the early part of the refractory period. Identify the correct statement from the following:

options.label: A
options.text: Both the assertion and the reason statements are correct, and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion

options.label: B
options.text: Both the assertion and the reason statements are correct, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion

options.label: C
options.text: The assertion statement is incorrect, but the reason statement is correct

options.label: D
options.text: Both the assertion and the reason statements are incorrect

questions.correct_answer: A. Both the assertion and the reason statements are correct, and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Both the assertion and the reason statements are correct, and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion

questions.text: A graphical representation of body fluid and osmolarity was taken of a subject while exercising which led to sweating. Which type of Body fluid disturbance can be seen in given scenario?
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Hypoosmotic fluid loss

questions.text: Considering the intracellular environment, which cation is predominantly found in higher concentrations and plays a pivotal role in various cellular functions?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Potassium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Potassium (K⁺) is the most abundant intracellular cation, crucial for maintaining cellular function, particularly in generating the resting membrane potential and facilitating cellular processes.
  • ➤ Potassium (K⁺)

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect with respect to Resting Membrane Potential in Different Cell Types:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Smooth muscle: −8 to −12 mV

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Smooth muscle cells typically have a resting membrane potential of −50 to −60 mV , while −8 to −12 mV is characteristic of red blood cells.
  • ➤ −50 to −60 mV
  • ➤ −8 to −12 mV

questions.text: In a patient with gastrointestinal symptoms, the dysfunction of which cellular structure, associated with the transmembrane protein Claudin, could potentially lead to altered permeability and paracellular transport?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tight Junctions

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Tight junctions , composed of proteins like Claudin and occludin , regulate paracellular permeability in the gastrointestinal tract, and their dysfunction can lead to altered absorption and water loss, contributing to gastrointestinal symptoms.
  • ➤ Tight junctions
  • ➤ Claudin
  • ➤ occludin

questions.text: Which one of the following is the true statement regarding skeletal muscle? Extracellular Ca2+ is not important for contraction Ca2+ released mainly from Mitochondria Ca2+ released from sarcoplasmic reticulum Voltage gated Ca2+ channels on sarcolemma has no role in EC coupling
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1, 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ In skeletal muscle , contraction primarily depends on calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum , and extracellular calcium is not necessary for contraction. Voltage-gated Ca²⁺ channels play a role in sensing depolarization and triggering calcium release, though they do not directly open for calcium influx.
  • ➤ skeletal muscle
  • ➤ sarcoplasmic reticulum

questions.text: The ICF concentration of K + is 140 mEq/L and ECF concentration is 14 mEq/L and cell is permeable only to K+. What would be the change expected of reducing the extracellular K + concentration from 14 to 1.4 millimolar?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 61 millivolts hyperpolarization

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ When extracellular K⁺ concentration is reduced, the cell undergoes 61 millivolts hyperpolarization , as the loss of K⁺ leads to the inside of the cell becoming more negative.
  • ➤ 61 millivolts hyperpolarization

questions.text: Where do afferent fibers from baroreceptors primarily project for blood pressure control?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Nucleus Tractus Solitarius

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Afferent fibers from the baroreceptors primarily project to the Nucleus Tractus Solitarius (NTS) , which integrates blood pressure information and regulates autonomic responses.
  • ➤ baroreceptors
  • ➤ Nucleus Tractus Solitarius (NTS)

questions.text: Which of the following statements are correct regarding mechanisms of depolarisation, repolarisation, and hyperpolarisation in a skeletal muscle action potential? Depolarization due to influx of Na⁺ through voltage-gated channels Depolarization due to influx of Na⁺ through ligand-gated channels Repolarization due to efflux of K⁺ through a voltage-gated channel Repolarization due to efflux of K⁺ through a ligand-gated channel Hyperpolarization due to slow closure of K⁺ channels
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1, 3 and 5 are correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Depolarization in skeletal muscle is driven by voltage-gated Na⁺ channels , repolarization is caused by voltage-gated K⁺ channels , and hyperpolarization results from the slow closure of K⁺ channels .
  • ➤ voltage-gated Na⁺ channels
  • ➤ voltage-gated K⁺ channels
  • ➤ slow closure of K⁺ channels

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about cardiac muscle contraction? Extracellular Ca2+ is important for contraction Ca2+ is released from mitochondria Ca2+ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum Ligand-gated Ca2+ channels on sarcolemma have no role in EC coupling
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1 and 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ In cardiac muscle contraction, both extracellular calcium and calcium released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum are crucial for the process, and voltage-gated calcium channels on the sarcolemma play an important role in excitation-contraction coupling.
  • ➤ extracellular calcium
  • ➤ sarcoplasmic reticulum

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient visits his family practitioner for a yearly examination. On examination, his BP was 190/100 mm Hg. His pulse pressure was 90 mm Hg. What would have decreased, resulting in this increase in pulse pressure?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Arterial wall compliance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Decreased arterial wall compliance (as seen in conditions like atherosclerosis) leads to an increase in pulse pressure by causing higher systolic pressure and lower diastolic pressure due to reduced elasticity and recoil of the arteries.
  • ➤ Decreased arterial wall compliance

questions.text: Arrange the sequence of events occurring after the P wave in an ECG: a wave in JVP First heart sound Rapid filling of ventricles T wave in ECG
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1-2-4-3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The correct sequence following the P wave involves:
  • ➤ P wave
  • ➤ Atrial contraction (a wave in JVP) , First heart sound (AV valve closure) , T wave (ventricular repolarization) , Rapid ventricular filling .
  • ➤ Atrial contraction (a wave in JVP) ,
  • ➤ Atrial contraction (a wave in JVP)
  • ➤ First heart sound (AV valve closure) ,
  • ➤ First heart sound (AV valve closure)
  • ➤ T wave (ventricular repolarization) ,
  • ➤ T wave (ventricular repolarization)
  • ➤ Rapid ventricular filling .
  • ➤ Rapid ventricular filling
  • ➤ Thus, the correct sequence is B) 1-2-4-3 .
  • ➤ B) 1-2-4-3

questions.text: A 19-year-old male severs an artery in a motorcycle accident. A bystander applies a tourniquet to stop the bleeding. When the paramedics arrived, the blood pressure of the injured man was only slightly hypotensive. The greatest percentage of the redistributed blood volume came from which of the following?
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Veins

questions.text: In a 42-year-old male, during the clinical examination, his blood pressure was found to be 132/82 mm Hg, heart rate was 70/min and respiratory rate was 18/min. What would be the stroke volume in this patient, if his cardiac output was 4.9 L?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 70 mL

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The stroke volume is the amount of blood pumped by the heart per beat. In this case, with a cardiac output of 4.9 L/min and a heart rate of 70 beats/min, the stroke volume is 70 mL per beat.
  • ➤ stroke volume
  • ➤ 70 mL

questions.text: All of the following statements about the flow of blood in a blood vessel are true, except:

options.label: A
options.text: The blood flow will be inversely proportional to the pressure difference

options.label: B
options.text: The blood flow will be directly proportional to the radius

options.label: C
options.text: The blood flow will be inversely proportional to the length

options.label: D
options.text: The blood flow will be inversely proportional to the viscosity

questions.correct_answer: A. The blood flow will be inversely proportional to the pressure difference
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) The blood flow will be inversely proportional to the pressure difference

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ According to Poiseuille's Law , blood flow is directly proportional to the pressure difference and vessel radius , and inversely proportional to vessel length and blood viscosity .
  • ➤ Poiseuille's Law
  • ➤ directly proportional
  • ➤ pressure difference
  • ➤ vessel radius
  • ➤ vessel length
  • ➤ blood viscosity

questions.text: Amongst different types of blood vessels, the tendency for turbulent flow is maximum in which one of the following vessels?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Aorta

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The aorta is the blood vessel most prone to turbulent flow due to its large diameter and the high velocity of blood flow, particularly after ventricular contraction.
  • ➤ aorta
  • ➤ large diameter
  • ➤ high velocity

questions.text: Match the following steps of ventricular action potential in the correct order:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) A-2, B-3, C-4, D-1, E-5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The correct matching is:
  • ➤ A-2 : Opening of voltage-gated calcium channels → Phase 2 B-3 : Repolarizing K⁺ currents → Phase 3 C-4 : Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels → Phase 0 D-1 : Transient outward flow of potassium → Phase 1 E-5 : Leaky sodium channel → No role
  • ➤ A-2 : Opening of voltage-gated calcium channels → Phase 2
  • ➤ A-2
  • ➤ B-3 : Repolarizing K⁺ currents → Phase 3
  • ➤ B-3
  • ➤ C-4 : Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels → Phase 0
  • ➤ C-4
  • ➤ D-1 : Transient outward flow of potassium → Phase 1
  • ➤ D-1
  • ➤ E-5 : Leaky sodium channel → No role
  • ➤ E-5
  • ➤ Thus, the correct answer is C) A-2, B-3, C-4, D-1, E-5 .
  • ➤ C) A-2, B-3, C-4, D-1, E-5

questions.text: According to Frank-Starling law, stroke volume and cardiac output is directly proportional to: ​​​​​​​
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Preload on the heart.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a measure of stroke volume?

options.label: A
options.text: Left ventricular end diastolic volume minus left ventricular end systolic volume

options.label: B
options.text: Ejection fraction times left ventricular end diastolic volume

questions.correct_answer: C. Ejection fraction times cardiac output
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ejection fraction times cardiac output

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ While stroke volume can be derived using left ventricular volumes (EDV and ESV) or calculated from ejection fraction and EDV , multiplying ejection fraction by cardiac output does not yield stroke volume, making option C the correct answer.
  • ➤ left ventricular volumes
  • ➤ ejection fraction and EDV
  • ➤ ejection fraction by cardiac output
  • ➤ option C

questions.text: In a patient, the hypothalamic thermostat was reset from point V to point X as shown below. Which of the following happens in stage W compared to stage Y?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Shivering

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ When the hypothalamic set point is raised (e.g., during a fever), the body initially responds by increasing heat production through mechanisms like shivering , which occurs during stage W when the body temperature is lower than the new set point.
  • ➤ shivering
  • ➤ stage W

questions.text: A 63-year-old male with a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy presents to the emergency department with acute onset of dizziness, marked hypotension, and bradycardia after taking an intravenous herbal supplement he found online. The emergency team, suspecting a potential reflex activation due to an unknown compound in the supplement, reminiscent of the effects seen with Veratrum alkaloids, which one of the following is true regarding the same reflex?

options.label: A
options.text: Activation of carotid body chemoreceptors leads to the reflex condition.

options.label: B
options.text: Stimulation of aortic arch stretch receptors induces the reflex.

options.label: C
options.text: Chemical stimulation of left ventricular receptors triggers the Bezold-Jarisch reflex.

options.label: D
options.text: Peripheral vasodilation by direct action on vascular smooth muscle initiates the reflex.

questions.correct_answer: C. Chemical stimulation of left ventricular receptors triggers the Bezold-Jarisch reflex.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Chemical stimulation of left ventricular receptors triggers the Bezold-Jarisch reflex.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The Bezold-Jarisch reflex is triggered by chemical stimulation of ventricular receptors , typically in the left ventricle , leading to a triad of hypotension, bradycardia , and decreased respiratory rate . This reflex is often associated with compounds such as Veratrum alkaloids , serotonin, and capsaicin.
  • ➤ Bezold-Jarisch reflex
  • ➤ ventricular receptors
  • ➤ left ventricle
  • ➤ hypotension, bradycardia
  • ➤ decreased respiratory rate
  • ➤ Veratrum alkaloids

questions.text: Which curve among the following represents the production of gamma-globin chains?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Yellow Curve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The gamma-globin chains are predominant during fetal life and are represented by the yellow curve in the graph. These chains are gradually replaced by beta-globin after birth, resulting in the transition from fetal hemoglobin ( HbF ) to adult hemoglobin ( HbA ).
  • ➤ gamma-globin
  • ➤ yellow curve
  • ➤ beta-globin
  • ➤ HbF
  • ➤ HbA

questions.text: Which of the following increases in COPD (Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease)? FRC (Functional Residual Capacity) TLC (Total Lung Capacity) VC (Vital Capacity) FEV1/FVC (Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second/Forced Vital Capacity)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1 and 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ In COPD , FRC and TLC increase due to air trapping and hyperinflation, while the FEV1/FVC ratio decreases due to obstructive airway changes. VC generally decreases or remains normal.
  • ➤ COPD
  • ➤ FRC
  • ➤ TLC
  • ➤ FEV1/FVC ratio
  • ➤ VC

questions.text: The oxygen taken up by the lungs is 200 ml per minute. Oxygen concentration in samples taken from the systemic and pulmonary arteries is 0.2 ml/ml and 0.16 ml/ml, respectively. What is the cardiac output?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 5.0 L/min

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • To calculate cardiac output, we can use the Fick Principle , which states:
  • • Fick Principle
  • • Where:
  • • Oxygen consumption = 200 ml/min (given) Arterial oxygen content = 0.2 ml/ml Venous oxygen content = 0.16 ml/ml
  • • Oxygen consumption = 200 ml/min (given)
  • • Oxygen consumption
  • • Arterial oxygen content = 0.2 ml/ml
  • • Arterial oxygen content
  • • Venous oxygen content = 0.16 ml/ml
  • • Venous oxygen content
  • • Step-by-step calculation:
  • • Step-by-step calculation:
  • • Oxygen consumption = 200 ml/min Difference in oxygen concentration between arterial and venous blood = 0.2 ml/ml−0.16 ml/ml=0.04 ml/ml
  • • Oxygen consumption = 200 ml/min
  • • Difference in oxygen concentration between arterial and venous blood = 0.2 ml/ml−0.16 ml/ml=0.04 ml/ml
  • • Now, applying the Fick equation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The cardiac output is 5.0 L/min , calculated using the Fick Principle based on the oxygen consumption and the difference between arterial and venous oxygen content.
  • ➤ 5.0 L/min

questions.text: Which of the following does this graph signify? ​​​​​​​
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Obstructive lung disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The graph showing decreased FEV1 percentage strongly indicates Obstructive Lung Disease (OLD) , such as COPD or asthma, rather than restrictive lung disease or normal lung function.
  • ➤ Obstructive Lung Disease (OLD)

questions.text: Pulmonary compliance: ​​​​​​​

options.label: B
options.text: Is defined as the change in pressure per unit change in volume

options.label: C
options.text: Compliance is slightly greater when measured during deflation than when measured during inflation

questions.correct_answer: C. Compliance is slightly greater when measured during deflation than when measured during inflation
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Compliance is slightly greater when measured during deflation than when measured during inflation.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Pulmonary compliance is a measure of how easily the lungs can be stretched or expanded. It is increased in conditions like emphysema and decreased in pulmonary fibrosis . Additionally, compliance is slightly greater during deflation than inflation due to hysteresis .
  • ➤ Pulmonary compliance
  • ➤ increased
  • ➤ emphysema
  • ➤ decreased
  • ➤ pulmonary fibrosis
  • ➤ hysteresis

questions.text: In regional ventilation and perfusion of the lung, which of the following is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Upper regions of the lung ventilate better than the lower regions

options.label: B
options.text: When supine the apical and basal ventilation is equal

options.label: C
options.text: V/Q ratio increases down the lung

options.label: D
options.text: The highest alveolar PO 2 is at the base of the lung

questions.correct_answer: B. When supine the apical and basal ventilation is equal
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) When supine the apical and basal ventilation is equal.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ In the supine position , ventilation becomes more evenly distributed between the apical and basal regions of the lung. In the upright position , ventilation is better at the base, and the V/Q ratio decreases as you move from the apex to the base.
  • ➤ supine position
  • ➤ apical and basal regions
  • ➤ upright position
  • ➤ V/Q ratio decreases

questions.text: A healthy, 25-year-old medical student participates in a 20-kilometer charity run for the Indian Medical Association. Which muscles does the student use (contract) during expiration?
questions.correct_answer: C. Internal intercostals and abdominal recti
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Internal intercostals and abdominal recti

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ During forceful expiration , such as during exercise or physical exertion, the internal intercostals and abdominal muscles contract to actively expel air from the lungs. The diaphragm and external intercostals are involved in inspiration, not expiration.
  • ➤ forceful expiration
  • ➤ internal intercostals
  • ➤ abdominal muscles

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true?

options.label: A
options.text: The change in the volume of the lungs with pressure is a measure of their compliance

options.label: B
options.text: The total compliance of the chest is determined solely by the compliance of the lungs

options.label: C
options.text: The recoil of the lungs assists inspiration

options.label: D
options.text: Pulmonary surfactant maintains a constant low surface tension in the alveoli

questions.correct_answer: A. The change in the volume of the lungs with pressure is a measure of their compliance
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) The change in the volume of the lungs with pressure is a measure of their compliance.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The change in lung volume in response to pressure changes is a key measure of lung compliance , which is essential for understanding how easily the lungs can stretch. The total compliance of the respiratory system depends on both the lungs and the chest wall, and lung recoil aids expiration , not inspiration.
  • ➤ change in lung volume in response to pressure changes
  • ➤ lung compliance
  • ➤ expiration

questions.text: Which characteristic physiological response pattern is associated with a pulmonary reflex mechanism stimulated by the activation of pulmonary J-receptors, specifically related to the release of inflammatory mediators or pulmonary congestion in conditions such as pulmonary edema or interstitial lung disease?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Slow breathing, bradycardia, hypotension

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The J-receptor reflex , activated by pulmonary congestion, inflammatory mediators, or pulmonary edema, initially causes slow breathing (bradypnea) , bradycardia , and hypotension through vagal stimulation. This is the immediate physiological response before any secondary compensatory mechanisms kick in.
  • ➤ J-receptor reflex
  • ➤ slow breathing (bradypnea)
  • ➤ bradycardia
  • ➤ hypotension

questions.text: A 27-year-old man is breathing quietly. He then inhales as much air as possible and exhales as much air as he can, producing the spirogram shown in the below figure. What is his expiratory reserve volume (in liters)?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 2.0

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The expiratory reserve volume (ERV) is defined as the extra amount of air that can be forcibly exhaled after the end of a normal, quiet expiration. This can be calculated using the spirogram.
  • • expiratory reserve volume (ERV)
  • • From the spirogram:
  • • The baseline of the quiet breathing (before deep inhalation and exhalation) is at 3 liters . After the forced expiration, the volume falls to 1 liter (this is the residual volume, the air that cannot be exhaled).
  • • The baseline of the quiet breathing (before deep inhalation and exhalation) is at 3 liters .
  • • baseline
  • • 3 liters
  • • After the forced expiration, the volume falls to 1 liter (this is the residual volume, the air that cannot be exhaled).
  • • 1 liter
  • • The ERV is the difference between the volume after normal expiration (3 L) and the volume after maximal exhalation (1 L).
  • • ERV
  • • So, 3 L−1 L=2 L
  • • 3 L−1 L=2 L
  • • Thus, the expiratory reserve volume (ERV) is 2.0 liters .
  • • expiratory reserve volume (ERV)
  • • 2.0 liters

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Expiratory reserve volume (ERV) is the volume of air that can be forcibly exhaled after a normal expiration. In this case, it is calculated as 2.0 liters , which is the difference between the volume after quiet expiration and the volume after forced expiration.
  • ➤ Expiratory reserve volume (ERV)
  • ➤ 2.0 liters

questions.text: Which one of the following definitions is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: The respiratory minute volume equals the amount of air inspired per minute.

options.label: B
options.text: Residual volume is the air left in the lungs after a maximal expiratory effort

options.label: C
options.text: Vital capacity is the maximal amount of air that can be expired after a normal inspiration

options.label: D
options.text: Physiological dead space is the amount of air not equilibrating with blood.

questions.correct_answer: C. Vital capacity is the maximal amount of air that can be expired after a normal inspiration
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vital capacity is the maximal amount of air that can be expired after a normal inspiration.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Vital capacity is the maximal amount of air that can be expelled after a forceful inspiration , not a normal inspiration. It consists of the inspiratory reserve volume, tidal volume, and expiratory reserve volume.
  • ➤ Vital capacity
  • ➤ maximal amount of air that can be expelled after a forceful inspiration

questions.text: Which of the following neurons predominantly fire during forceful expiration?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ventral group of neurons

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The ventral respiratory group (VRG) of neurons is activated during forceful expiration , such as during exercise, and is responsible for sending signals to muscles that help forcibly expel air from the lungs.
  • ➤ ventral respiratory group (VRG)
  • ➤ forceful expiration

questions.text: Transcutaneous electric nerve stimulation is used to reduce pain. What is the mechanism behind this?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Gate control theory

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Transcutaneous electric nerve stimulation (TENS) reduces pain by stimulating large sensory fibers, which modulate the transmission of pain signals through the gate control theory , effectively "closing the gate" to pain signals traveling to the brain.
  • ➤ Transcutaneous electric nerve stimulation (TENS)
  • ➤ gate control theory

questions.text: Which one of the following statements accurately describes a neurological phenomenon commonly observed in motor control and pivotal in maintaining appropriate muscle tension, involving a specific neuronal pathway with interneuronal processing between sensory and motor neurons, regulating muscle contraction by modulating motor neuron activity based on Golgi tendon organ input?

options.label: A
options.text: Occurs when Ia spindle afferents are inhibited.

options.label: B
options.text: Is a monosynaptic reflex initiated by activation of the Golgi tendon organ?

options.label: C
options.text: Is a disynaptic reflex with a single interneuron inserted between the afferent and efferent limbs.

options.label: D
options.text: Uses type II afferent fibers from the Golgi tendon organ

questions.correct_answer: C. Is a disynaptic reflex with a single interneuron inserted between the afferent and efferent limbs.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Is a disynaptic reflex with a single interneuron inserted between the afferent and efferent limbs.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The Golgi tendon organ reflex is a disynaptic reflex , involving an inhibitory interneuron that modulates alpha motor neuron activity to reduce muscle tension, preventing potential injury from excessive force.
  • ➤ Golgi tendon organ reflex
  • ➤ disynaptic reflex

questions.text: What waves are shown as X & Y below: ​​​​​​​
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Alpha and delta

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The alpha waves (X) range from 8-13 Hz and are typically seen in a relaxed, awake state, while delta waves (Y) have a frequency of 0-3 Hz and are seen during deep sleep.
  • ➤ alpha waves
  • ➤ delta waves

questions.text: A motorcyclist suffered head injury 6 months back and presents with persistent memory deficits following the injury. Choose the most appropriately matched option related to memory.
questions.correct_answer: C. Medial temporal lobe - Declarative memory
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Medial temporal lobe - Declarative memory

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The medial temporal lobe , including the hippocampus , is central to the formation and recall of declarative (explicit) memory , which involves conscious recall of facts and events. Damage to this region, such as after a head injury, can lead to persistent memory deficits related to declarative memory.
  • ➤ medial temporal lobe
  • ➤ hippocampus
  • ➤ declarative (explicit) memory
  • ➤ persistent memory deficits

questions.text: How would you categorize a situation where a single neuron receives inputs from 150 sensory neurons, totaling to 400 inputs?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Convergence

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Convergence describes the process where a single neuron receives inputs from many other neurons . In this scenario, a single neuron is receiving inputs from 150 sensory neurons , which is an example of convergence, facilitating the integration of information from multiple sources.
  • ➤ Convergence
  • ➤ single neuron receives inputs from many other neurons
  • ➤ 150 sensory neurons

questions.text: While studying the stimulus given at different time intervals and their responses, Pavlov performed various experiments on dogs. In Pavlov’s famous experiment, the dog shows which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Conditional response

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ In Pavlov's famous classical conditioning experiment, the dog’s salivation in response to the sound of the bell is a conditioned response , as the dog learned to associate the bell with food through repeated pairings.
  • ➤ conditioned response

questions.text: A patient after a head injury following a road traffic accident presents with the following symptoms: extreme curiosity, forgetfulness, hyperorality, and increased sex drive. Which of the following structures is most likely to be damaged in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Gray matter around aqueduct of Sylvius

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Amygdala

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The amygdala is most likely damaged in patients with symptoms of Klüver-Bucy syndrome , including hyperorality , hypersexuality , memory deficits , and extreme curiosity , often following a head injury.
  • ➤ amygdala
  • ➤ Klüver-Bucy syndrome
  • ➤ hyperorality
  • ➤ hypersexuality
  • ➤ memory deficits
  • ➤ extreme curiosity

questions.text: How is the muscle spindle able to detect the length while the muscle is contracting?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Nuclear bag fibers

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The nuclear bag fibers in the muscle spindle detect the dynamic changes in muscle length during contraction, making them responsible for providing feedback to the central nervous system about muscle activity.
  • ➤ nuclear bag fibers
  • ➤ dynamic changes in muscle length

questions.text: A 53-year-old male is brought to the emergency department with complaints of right-sided weakness and jargon speech. A CT brain was ordered to rule out hemorrhagic stroke. On neurological examination, there is normal object recognition but loss of comprehension. Which of the following areas is affected?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Superior temporal gyrus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The superior temporal gyrus (Wernicke’s area) is responsible for language comprehension, and damage to this area results in fluent aphasia (jargon speech), where comprehension is impaired, but speech production remains fluent.
  • ➤ superior temporal gyrus (Wernicke’s area)
  • ➤ fluent aphasia

questions.text: All of the following can be seen in lower motor neuron lesions, except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hyperreflexia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ In lower motor neuron lesions , symptoms such as flaccidity , hypotonia , and fasciculations are common, but hyperreflexia is a feature of upper motor neuron lesions .
  • ➤ lower motor neuron lesions
  • ➤ flaccidity
  • ➤ hypotonia
  • ➤ fasciculations
  • ➤ hyperreflexia
  • ➤ upper motor neuron lesions

questions.text: A 28-year-old man was seen by a neurologist because he had experienced prolonged episodes of tingling and numbness in his right arm. He underwent a neurologic exam to evaluate his sensory nervous system . Which of the following cutaneous mechanoreceptors is correctly paired with the type of stimulus to which it is most apt to respond?
questions.correct_answer: A. Pacinian corpuscle and rapid vibration
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pacinian corpuscle and rapid vibration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The Pacinian corpuscles are mechanoreceptors that respond to rapid vibration and pressure changes, making them the correct pairing for detecting tingling and vibratory sensations in the skin.
  • ➤ Pacinian corpuscles
  • ➤ rapid vibration

questions.text: A 47-year-old male with a pituitary mass causing stalk compression is evaluated for hormonal imbalances. This condition often leads to altered secretion of various pituitary hormones. Which of the following hormones is least likely to have decreased secretion due to sectioning of the pituitary stalk?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Prolactin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ In pituitary stalk compression , most hormones experience decreased secretion , but prolactin is an exception. Due to the loss of dopamine's inhibitory control , prolactin secretion is increased , making it the least likely hormone to decrease in such conditions.
  • ➤ pituitary stalk compression
  • ➤ decreased secretion
  • ➤ prolactin
  • ➤ dopamine's inhibitory control
  • ➤ increased

questions.text: Platelet derived growth factor acts through which one of the following pathways?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Tyrosine Kinase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) acts through the tyrosine kinase pathway , a common pathway for growth factors that regulate cell growth, proliferation, and survival.
  • ➤ Platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF)
  • ➤ tyrosine kinase pathway

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the physician with a significantly enlarged thyroid gland. Serum T3/T4 levels are decreased. Iodine deficiency is suspected. Which of the following is the function of thyroid peroxidase in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Oxidation of iodide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Thyroid peroxidase (TPO) is responsible for the oxidation of iodide to iodine , a critical step in thyroid hormone synthesis. This function is essential for producing thyroid hormones, particularly in conditions of iodine deficiency.
  • ➤ Thyroid peroxidase (TPO)
  • ➤ oxidation of iodide to iodine

questions.text: During starvation, the graph of three substances is plotted as shown below. The scale for A and B is on the left, and the scale for C is on the right. Which of the substances are represented by curve B?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) T3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ During starvation, T3 levels (curve B) drop significantly as part of the body’s mechanism to reduce metabolic activity, while reverse T3 (RT3) increases to further downregulate metabolic processes.
  • ➤ T3 levels (curve B)
  • ➤ reverse T3 (RT3)

questions.text: Polyphagia in diabetes is mainly due to:

options.label: A
options.text: Decreased glucose utilization in most of the tissues of the body

options.label: B
options.text: Increased glucose uptake by the whole brain

options.label: C
options.text: Decreased glucose utilization by entire hypothalamus nuclei

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased glucose utilization of VM nucleus of Hypothalamus

questions.correct_answer: D. Decreased glucose utilization of VM nucleus of Hypothalamus
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Decreased glucose utilization of VM nucleus of Hypothalamus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Polyphagia in diabetes is mainly due to the decreased glucose utilization in the ventromedial nucleus (VM nucleus) of the hypothalamus , which leads to the persistent activation of the hunger center and an unregulated feeling of hunger.
  • ➤ Polyphagia
  • ➤ decreased glucose utilization in the ventromedial nucleus (VM nucleus) of the hypothalamus

questions.text: Many signaling pathways involve the generation of inositol trisphosphate (IP3) and diacylglycerol (DAG). These molecules:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Are derived from PIP2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ IP3 and DAG are key second messengers generated from PIP2 by the action of phospholipase C in response to certain extracellular signals, and they help propagate cellular responses through calcium release and activation of protein kinase C .
  • ➤ IP3
  • ➤ DAG
  • ➤ PIP2
  • ➤ phospholipase C
  • ➤ protein kinase C

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient experiencing irregular menstrual cycles and seeking guidance from her healthcare provider. During the visit, the healthcare team explores factors influencing reproductive hormone regulation. Which of the following have a role in controlling the secretion of Prolactin?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Dopamine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Dopamine acts as a prolactin-inhibiting hormone (PIH) and is the primary regulator of prolactin secretion . Decreased dopamine activity can lead to increased prolactin levels.
  • ➤ Dopamine
  • ➤ prolactin-inhibiting hormone (PIH)
  • ➤ prolactin secretion

questions.text: Which one of the following is an indirect action of growth hormone?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Anti-lipolysis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The indirect actions of growth hormone are primarily mediated through IGF-1 , and anti-lipolysis is one of these indirect effects. Lipolysis , insulin reduction , and sodium retention are direct effects of growth hormone.
  • ➤ indirect actions
  • ➤ IGF-1
  • ➤ anti-lipolysis
  • ➤ Lipolysis
  • ➤ insulin reduction
  • ➤ sodium retention

questions.text: "Vasopressin escape" in SIADH results due to:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Downregulation of aquaporin 2 production

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ In vasopressin escape , the body downregulates aquaporin-2 production and its insertion into the collecting duct membrane, thereby reducing water reabsorption and preventing further fluid overload in patients with SIADH .
  • ➤ vasopressin escape
  • ➤ aquaporin-2 production
  • ➤ SIADH

questions.text: Urticaria is seen in a patient. The DLC (Differential Leukocyte Count) that was done will most probably show?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Eosinophilia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ In patients with urticaria or allergic reactions, the DLC is most likely to show eosinophilia as eosinophils increase in response to help regulate and mitigate the allergic process.
  • ➤ urticaria
  • ➤ DLC
  • ➤ eosinophilia

questions.text: Hypoxia inducible factor 1 alpha stimulates which of the following cells to stimulate bone marrow for RBC production?
questions.correct_answer: C. Interstitial cells of peritubular capillary
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Interstitial cells of peritubular capillary

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Hypoxia Inducible Factor 1 alpha (HIF-1α) stimulates the production of erythropoietin from the interstitial cells of the peritubular capillaries in the kidney, which in turn stimulates the bone marrow for increased RBC production in response to hypoxia.
  • ➤ Hypoxia Inducible Factor 1 alpha (HIF-1α)
  • ➤ erythropoietin
  • ➤ interstitial cells of the peritubular capillaries

questions.text: Which of the following is not required for calculation of creatinine clearance?

options.label: D
options.text: Volume of serum passing through the kidney in 24 hours

questions.correct_answer: D. Volume of serum passing through the kidney in 24 hours
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Volume of serum passing through the kidney in 24 hours

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ For calculating creatinine clearance , urine creatinine , serum creatinine , and 24-hour urine output are required. The volume of serum passing through the kidneys (renal plasma flow) is not part of this calculation.
  • ➤ creatinine clearance
  • ➤ urine creatinine
  • ➤ serum creatinine
  • ➤ 24-hour urine output
  • ➤ volume of serum passing through the kidneys
  • ➤ not

questions.text: This is the graph depicting the filterability of dextran through the kidney, with 1 representing complete filtration and 0 representing no filtration. Choose the substance A, B, C respectively. ​​​​​​​
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Polycationic, Neutral, Polyanionic

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ In the context of glomerular filtration, cationic (positively charged) molecules are filtered more readily than neutral and anionic (negatively charged) molecules, due to the negative charge of the glomerular filtration barrier.
  • ➤ cationic (positively charged)
  • ➤ neutral
  • ➤ anionic (negatively charged)

questions.text: If glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure is 60 mmHg, Bowman’s capsule hydrostatic pressure is 15 mmHg, glomerular oncotic pressure is 30 mmHg, and Bowman’s capsule oncotic pressure is 5 mmHg, the net filtration pressure will be ________ mmHg.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 20

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The net filtration pressure is determined by balancing the hydrostatic and oncotic pressures between the glomerular capillaries and Bowman’s capsule, and in this case, the calculated pressure is 20 mmHg .
  • ➤ 20 mmHg

questions.text: A 77-year-old man comes to the physician because of swelling of his legs and feet for 6 months. He has a 40-year history of alcoholism and a 5-year history of hepatic disease. Physical examination shows ascites and edema of the lower extremities. A decrease in which of the following most likely promotes edema formation in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Plasma colloid oncotic pressure

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ In patients with hepatic disease , the decrease in plasma colloid oncotic pressure due to impaired protein production (especially albumin) is a key factor promoting edema and ascites formation.
  • ➤ hepatic disease
  • ➤ plasma colloid oncotic pressure
  • ➤ edema
  • ➤ ascites

questions.text: A patient has a creatinine clearance of 100 ml/min, a plasma K+ concentration of 4.0 mmol/L, a urine flow rate of 2.0 ml/min, and a urine K+ concentration of 60 mmol/L. What is his approximate rate of K+ excretion?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 0.12 mmol/min

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The rate of excretion of a substance can be calculated by multiplying its concentration in the urine by the urine flow rate. In this case, the patient's potassium excretion rate is 0.12 mmol/min .
  • ➤ rate of excretion
  • ➤ 0.12 mmol/min

questions.text: In response to an increase in GFR, the proximal tubule and the loop of Henle demonstrate an increase in the rate of Na+ reabsorption. This phenomenon is called? ​​​​​​​
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Glomerulo tubular balance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Glomerulo-tubular balance is a mechanism that adjusts sodium reabsorption in proportion to the GFR , ensuring that sodium and water are reabsorbed efficiently to prevent excessive loss when GFR increases.
  • ➤ Glomerulo-tubular balance
  • ➤ GFR

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department in an unconscious state. An arterial blood analysis was done revealing the values shown. Identify the patient’s condition. ​​​​​​​
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Metabolic acidosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The patient’s unconscious state , combined with a low pH , low bicarbonate , and normal or low pCO2 , points to metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation.
  • ➤ unconscious state
  • ➤ low pH
  • ➤ low bicarbonate
  • ➤ normal or low pCO2
  • ➤ metabolic acidosis

questions.text: Which of the following hormones do not act on the pancreas?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Gastrin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Gastrin primarily acts on the stomach and not the pancreas, making it the hormone that does not act on the pancreas in this context.
  • ➤ Gastrin
  • ➤ stomach
  • ➤ does not

questions.text: Which of the following hormone is reported to promote the maturation of the hypothalamic gonadal axis during puberty?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Leptin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Leptin is responsible for initiating the pulsatile release of GnRH , which is necessary for the maturation of the hypothalamic gonadal axis during puberty.
  • ➤ Leptin
  • ➤ pulsatile release of GnRH
  • ➤ hypothalamic gonadal axis

questions.text: The migrating motor complex (MMC) in humans:

options.label: A
options.text: Occurs only in the small intestine

options.label: B
options.text: Requires an intact intrinsic nervous system for coordinated propagation

options.label: C
options.text: Is the result of food-mediated distension of the small intestine

options.label: D
options.text: Mixes intestinal contents with bile and the digestive enzymes

questions.correct_answer: B. Requires an intact intrinsic nervous system for coordinated propagation
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Requires an intact intrinsic nervous system for coordinated propagation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The Migrating Motor Complex (MMC) is an essential cleaning mechanism of the fasting gastrointestinal tract that relies on the intact intrinsic nervous system , specifically the myenteric plexus , to function properly.
  • ➤ Migrating Motor Complex (MMC)
  • ➤ fasting gastrointestinal tract
  • ➤ intact intrinsic nervous system
  • ➤ myenteric plexus

questions.text: The most common cause of iron deficiency anemia is lack of dietary intake of iron. Iron is transported from the enterocyte to the capillary through:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ferroportin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Ferroportin is responsible for transporting iron from the enterocytes into the capillaries , playing a key role in iron absorption and homeostasis.
  • ➤ Ferroportin
  • ➤ enterocytes
  • ➤ capillaries

questions.text: The hypothalamus and fat tissues play an important role in the regulation of energy metabolism. Leptin acts by increasing the activity of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Alpha MSH

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Leptin increases the activity of Alpha MSH , which promotes satiety and plays a crucial role in energy metabolism and the regulation of food intake.
  • ➤ Leptin
  • ➤ Alpha MSH
  • ➤ satiety

questions.text: Which of the following is the incorrect match?

options.label: A
options.text: Gastrin from G cells from stomach

options.label: B
options.text: Motilin from Mo cells from duodenum and jejunum

options.label: C
options.text: CCK from K cell of duodenum and pancreas

options.label: D
options.text: Secretin from S cells of duodenum and jejunum

questions.correct_answer: C. CCK from K cell of duodenum and pancreas
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) CCK from K cell of duodenum and pancreas

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Cholecystokinin (CCK) is secreted by I cells in the duodenum and jejunum, and the incorrect match in this case is option C .
  • ➤ Cholecystokinin (CCK)
  • ➤ I cells
  • ➤ option C

questions.text: All of the following are true about secretin except:

options.label: A
options.text: It is secreted by S cells of intestine

options.label: B
options.text: It causes release of alkaline pancreatic juice rich in enzymes

options.label: C
options.text: Its action is mediated via intracellular cAMP

questions.correct_answer: B. It causes release of alkaline pancreatic juice rich in enzymes
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) It causes release of alkaline pancreatic juice rich in enzymes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Secretin stimulates the release of bicarbonate-rich pancreatic juice to neutralize acidic chyme, but the enzyme-rich secretion is stimulated by cholecystokinin (CCK) , not secretin.
  • ➤ Secretin
  • ➤ bicarbonate-rich
  • ➤ enzyme-rich
  • ➤ cholecystokinin (CCK)

questions.text: In the aftermath of a terrorist attack, humanitarian emergency volunteers handed out isotonic drink solutions containing NaCl and glucose to people with signs of dehydration. These oral rehydration solutions with NaCl and glucose are physiologically more effective than isotonic solutions containing NaCl only. Which of the following is the best explanation? ​​​​​​​

options.label: A
options.text: Primary active glucose transporter at the basolateral intestinal cell membrane facilitates Na+ and water reabsorption from the gut.

options.label: B
options.text: Oral glucose increases insulin secretion, which then facilitates water reabsorption.

options.label: C
options.text: The addition of glucose makes it more likely for the person to drink.

options.label: D
options.text: The cotransport of glucose and Na+ across the apical membrane of intestinal epithelial cells facilitates Na+ and water absorption from the gut.

questions.correct_answer: D. The cotransport of glucose and Na+ across the apical membrane of intestinal epithelial cells facilitates Na+ and water absorption from the gut.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) The cotransport of glucose and Na+ across the apical membrane of intestinal epithelial cells facilitates Na+ and water absorption from the gut.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The cotransport of glucose and sodium (via SGLT1) on the apical membrane of intestinal cells enhances sodium and water absorption , making oral rehydration solutions (ORS) containing both NaCl and glucose more effective for treating dehydration.
  • ➤ cotransport of glucose and sodium (via SGLT1)
  • ➤ sodium and water absorption

questions.text: From which of the following does the tetanic contraction of a skeletal muscle fiber result from a cumulative increase in the intracellular concentration?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ca++

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Tetanic contraction in skeletal muscle is primarily due to a cumulative increase in intracellular calcium (Ca++) , which sustains the contraction by enabling continuous cross-bridge formation.
  • ➤ Tetanic contraction
  • ➤ cumulative increase in intracellular calcium (Ca++)

questions.text: Which of the following statements are incorrect about vasopressin?

options.label: A
options.text: It's a more powerful vasoconstrictor than angiotensin II.

options.label: B
options.text: Concentration of circulating blood vasopressin after severe hemorrhage can increase enough to attenuate reductions in arterial pressure markedly.

options.label: C
options.text: Uses adenylyl cyclase-cAMP as well as phospholipase C system.

options.label: D
options.text: Secreted by paraventricular nucleus of hypothalamus

questions.correct_answer: D. Secreted by paraventricular nucleus of hypothalamus
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Secreted by paraventricular nucleus of hypothalamus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Vasopressin (ADH) is secreted by the supraoptic nucleus of the hypothalamus and acts as a potent vasoconstrictor and regulator of water reabsorption, while the paraventricular nucleus secretes oxytocin.
  • ➤ supraoptic nucleus
  • ➤ paraventricular nucleus

questions.text: A 35-year-old man visits his doctor because his wife has long complained of his snoring, but recently observed that his breathing stops for a couple of minutes at a time while he is sleeping. He undergoes polysomnography and ventilatory response testing to ascertain the extent and cause of his sleep apnea. The activity of the central chemoreceptors is stimulated by which of the following? ​​​​​​​

options.label: A
options.text: A decrease in the metabolic rate of the surrounding brain tissue

options.label: B
options.text: A decrease in the PO2 of blood flowing through the brain

options.label: C
options.text: An increase in the PCO2 of blood flowing through the brain

options.label: D
options.text: An increase in the pH of the CSF

questions.correct_answer: C. An increase in the PCO2 of blood flowing through the brain
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) An increase in the PCO2 of blood flowing through the brain

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Central chemoreceptors are primarily activated by an increase in PCO2 in the blood, which leads to increased H+ concentration and decreased pH in the CSF, thereby increasing respiratory drive.
  • ➤ Central chemoreceptors
  • ➤ PCO2
  • ➤ H+ concentration

questions.text: Physical examination of a 41-year-old narcotic abuser reveals an early systolic murmur. The physician also notes a 7 cm distance between the height of the blood in his right internal jugular vein and the sternal angle (normal = 3 cm). Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for the physical findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tricuspid regurgitation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The combination of an early systolic murmur and elevated JVP is most consistent with tricuspid regurgitation , a condition where blood flows back into the right atrium during systole, raising right atrial pressure and the JVP.
  • ➤ early systolic murmur
  • ➤ elevated JVP
  • ➤ tricuspid regurgitation

questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney disease presents with elevated serum potassium levels. Despite treatment, the patient remains at risk of hyperkalemia due to impaired renal excretion. The compartment of body fluid Which is primarily responsible for potassium regulation, what percentage does it represent as compared to Extracellular fluid?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Approximately 200%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The intracellular fluid (ICF) is the primary compartment responsible for potassium regulation , and it represents about 200% of the volume compared to the extracellular fluid (ECF) .
  • ➤ intracellular fluid (ICF)
  • ➤ potassium regulation
  • ➤ 200% of the volume
  • ➤ extracellular fluid (ECF)

questions.text: Countercurrent mechanism is present in which of the following parts of the body? Eye Testes Kidney Gut Skin
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 are correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The countercurrent mechanism is present in the eye , testes , kidney , gut , and skin , making all options in the question correct.
  • ➤ countercurrent mechanism
  • ➤ eye
  • ➤ testes
  • ➤ kidney
  • ➤ gut
  • ➤ skin

questions.text: What leads to the detachment of myosin from actin filaments during muscle contraction?

options.label: B
options.text: Cessation of calcium release from sarcoplasm

options.label: D
options.text: Attachment of ATP to myosin head

questions.correct_answer: D. Attachment of ATP to myosin head
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Attachment of ATP to myosin head

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The attachment of ATP to the myosin head leads to its detachment from actin , which is crucial for muscle relaxation and resetting the contractile cycle.
  • ➤ attachment of ATP to the myosin head
  • ➤ detachment from actin

questions.text: Assume that excess blood is transfused into a patient whose arterial baroreceptors are nonfunctional and blood pressure increases from 100 to 150 mm Hg. Then, assume that the same volume of blood is infused into the same patient under conditions where his arterial baroreceptors are functioning normally and blood pressure increases from 100 to 125 mm Hg. What is the approximate feedback "gain" of the arterial baroreceptors in this patient when they are functioning normally?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) −1.0

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The feedback "gain" in physiological systems like baroreceptor regulation is typically negative because the system corrects in the opposite direction of the error. In this case, the gain is −1.0 , reflecting the correction after a blood transfusion.
  • ➤ gain is −1.0

questions.text: If the membrane potential of this cell is −80 millivolts, the driving force is greatest for which ion?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ca++

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The driving force for ion movement depends on the difference between the membrane potential and the ion's equilibrium potential. Calcium (Ca++) experiences the greatest driving force due to its high equilibrium potential and the strong attraction to the negatively charged cell interior at −80 mV .
  • ➤ Calcium (Ca++)
  • ➤ −80 mV

questions.text: Fetal hemoglobin has higher affinity for oxygen due to: ​​​​​​​

options.label: D
options.text: Oxygen dissociation curve is shifted to the right

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Reduced 2,3-DPG binding

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Fetal hemoglobin has a higher affinity for oxygen primarily due to reduced 2,3-DPG binding , which allows for better oxygen binding in the fetal environment.
  • ➤ reduced 2,3-DPG binding

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman eats a high carbohydrate meal. Her plasma glucose concentration rises, and this results in increased insulin secretion from the pancreatic islet cells. Glucose-mediated insulin release is mediated through:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) ATP-sensitive K+ channels

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Glucose-mediated insulin release is primarily regulated through the closure of ATP-sensitive K+ channels , which triggers a cascade of events leading to insulin secretion.
  • ➤ Glucose-mediated insulin release
  • ➤ closure of ATP-sensitive K+ channels

questions.text: Different types of neurons evolved with unique properties and their function is related to it. In motor neurons, the site of generation of action potential is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Initial segment

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ In motor neurons , action potentials are generated at the initial segment , which is the most sensitive region for initiating these signals due to the high density of voltage-gated sodium channels.
  • ➤ motor neurons
  • ➤ initial segment

questions.text: Which among the following has the highest airway resistance?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bronchi

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The bronchi contribute the most to airway resistance due to their smaller total cross-sectional area compared to smaller airways, despite having a larger individual diameter.
  • ➤ bronchi

questions.text: All of the following ions have maximum reduction in their concentration on the luminal side of proximal convoluted tubule except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Chloride

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ While most ions are reabsorbed in the PCT , chloride experiences the least reduction in concentration compared to glucose, amino acids, and bicarbonate.
  • ➤ PCT
  • ➤ chloride

questions.text: The sodium iodide symporter is present in all of the following except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pituitary gland

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The sodium-iodide symporter (NIS) is primarily involved in tissues related to iodide uptake for thyroid hormone synthesis, but it is not found in the pituitary gland , which regulates thyroid function through hormone release rather than direct iodide transport.
  • ➤ sodium-iodide symporter (NIS)
  • ➤ pituitary gland
